message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy, which is effective in preventing mother-to-child transmission of the virus. However, the newborn should still be given prophylaxis to further decrease the risk of transmission. According to current guidelines, the recommended prophylactic regimen for newborns of HIV-positive mothers is zidovudine for 6 weeks. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management of this infant is to administer zidovudine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Administering zidovudine to the newborn within 6-12 hours of birth and continued for 6 weeks is the appropriate management for an infant born to an HIV-positive mother. The use of other antiretroviral drugs may be considered depending on the mother's viral load.

We refer to medical guidelines for help. The mother's use of antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy and her low viral load suggest a low risk of vertical transmission of HIV to the newborn. The current standard of care is to administer zidovudine to the newborn within the first 6-12 hours of life and continue for the first 6 weeks of life. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management of this infant is to administer zidovudine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Infants born to mothers with HIV should receive antiretroviral prophylaxis to prevent vertical transmission. Zidovudine is the first-line agent recommended for neonatal prophylaxis. Administering multiple agents is unnecessary in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy, which suggests a risk of perinatal transmission of HIV to the newborn. Zidovudine prophylaxis is recommended for all HIV-exposed newborns, in addition to antiretroviral therapy for those who test positive for HIV. Lamivudine and nevirapine are not sufficient on their own for prevention or treatment of HIV in newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn’s mother has HIV, and the newborn has no abnormalities, so prophylactic antiretroviral therapy is necessary to prevent HIV transmission. Zidovudine is the standard prophylactic antiretroviral therapy for infants born to mothers with HIV. The other options may be used in certain situations, but zidovudine is the most appropriate next step in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy, which reduces the transmission rate from mother to infant by 98%. Zidovudine is given as the standard of care for HIV-exposed infants, regardless of maternal viral load. Lamivudine and nevirapine may be added in certain situations, but zidovudine is always indicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy, and the newborn has not shown any abnormalities. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to administer zidovudine to the infant to reduce the risk of transmission of HIV. Other antiretrovirals may also be considered, but zidovudine is the standard of care.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HIV-positive mothers receive antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission. In this case, the newborn should receive zidovudine for post-exposure prophylaxis. The other options are not sufficient for post-exposure prophylaxis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. The most appropriate next step for the newborn is to administer zidovudine to reduce the risk of HIV transmission perinatally. Lamivudine and nevirapine may also be used, but zidovudine is the preferred initial treatment.
